message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on biology for help. The enzyme that the investigators have most likely isolated is DNA polymerase I, which has both 5' to 3' polymerase activity and 3' to 5' exonuclease (proofreading) activity. DNA ligase catalyzes the ligation of the okazaki fragments, Telomerase is responsible for adding repeating DNA sequences to the ends of linear chromosomes to prevent degradation, and Primase synthesizes RNA primers for DNA replication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. The enzyme isolated is active on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides, suggesting that it is a DNA polymerase. Among the options, only DNA polymerase I has both DNA polymerase and 3' to 5'exonuclease activity, and it can remove both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. DNA polymerase I has both polymerase and exonuclease activities and is involved in DNA replication in E. coli colonies. It also has the ability to remove both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides. DNA ligase joins the ends of DNA strands, telomerase extends the ends of chromosomes, and primase synthesizes RNA primers for DNA polymerase to extend.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. The enzyme that is involved in DNA replication and has exonuclease activity on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides is DNA polymerase I. DNA ligase is involved in sealing nicks in DNA strands, telomerase is involved in maintaining telomeres at the ends of chromosomes, and primase is involved in synthesizing RNA primers for DNA replication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. The activity of exonuclease on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides suggests that the investigators have isolated DNA polymerase I, which has both 5' to 3' exonuclease activity and 3' to 5' exonuclease activity that can remove mismatched or damaged nucleotides during DNA replication. DNA ligase catalyzes the formation of phosphodiester bonds between adjacent nucleotides. Telomerase adds telomere DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes to prevent shortening during replication. Primase synthesizes RNA primers that initiate synthesis of nascent DNA strands.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biology for help. The enzyme that is active on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides is likely DNA polymerase I, which has a 5' to 3' exonuclease activity that enables it to remove nucleotides that have been incorrectly incorporated into the growing strand. DNA ligase, telomerase, and primase do not have exonuclease activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biology for help. The enzyme in question is capable of cleaving both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides, which is a characteristic of DNA polymerase I. DNA ligase, Telomerase, and Primase have different functions and are not involved in DNA replication in the same way as DNA polymerase I.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the enzyme is active on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides suggests that it is a 5' to 3' exonuclease, which is a property of DNA polymerase I. DNA ligase is involved in joining Okazaki fragments while Telomerase is involved in elongating telomeres. Primase is used to synthesize RNA primers on the template DNA strand to initiate DNA synthesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. The exonuclease activity on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides suggests that the enzyme is a DNA polymerase. Among the options, only DNA polymerase I exhibits exonuclease activity on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on microbiology for help. The ability to act on both intact and demethylated thymine nucleotides suggests that the enzyme is a DNA polymerase. Among the options, only DNA polymerase I has exonuclease activity and is involved in DNA replication in E. coli colonies.
